DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: Alexis R Hernández;Alexis R. Hernández;Hernández A.;A. Hernández;A. R. Hernández;Hernández, A. R.;Hernández, Alexis;HERNÁNDEZ, ALEXIS R;HERNÁNDEZ, ALEXIS R.;HERNÁNDEZ, A.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: É professor adjunto do Instituto de Física da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro. Possui graduação e mestrado em Física pela Universidade Simón Bolívar - Venezuela (1999 e 2002 respectivamente) e doutorado do Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Físicas (2009). Tem experiência na área de física teórica, com ênfase em Física da Matéria Condensada. Utiliza ferramentas da teoria quântica de campos para estudar fenômenos de transporte eletrônico em sistemas mesoscópicos. Mais recentemente vem se desempenhando na física dos sistemas complexos.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Adjoint professor at the Rio de Janeiro Federal University. Bachelor and Master degree from Simon Bolivar University (1999 and 2002 respectively). PhD. from the Brazilian Center for Physical Research (2009). Has experience in theoretical physic, focusing on Condensed Matter. Use Quantum Field Theory techniques to study electronic transport phenomena on mesoscopic systems. More recently is working on Complex Systems.

DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO: A NETWORKED VOTING RULE FOR DEMOCRATIC REPRESENTATION
DADOS-BASICOS-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALH.TITULO-INGLES: A NETWORKED VOTING RULE FOR DEMOCRATIC REPRESENTATION

DETALHAMENTO-DA-APRESENTACAO-DE-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: 1st LATIN AMERICAN CONFERENCE ON COMPLEX NETWORKS (LANET 2017)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: We introduce a general framework for exploring the problem of selecting a committee of representatives with the aim of studying a networked voting rule based on a decentralized large scale platform, which can assure a strong accountability of the elected. The results of our simulations suggest that this algorithm-based approach is able to obtain a high representativeness for relatively small committees, performing even better than a classical voting rule based on a closed list of candidates. We show that a general relation between committee size and representatives exists in the form of an inverse square root law and that the normalized committee size approximately scales with the inverse of the community size, allowing the scalability to very large populations. These findings are not strongly influenced by the different networks used to describe the individuals interactions, except for the presence of few individuals with very high connectivity which can have a marginal negative effect in the committee selection process.
